div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The L massol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus, ot to the Manager, "Egyptian Gazette" Alexandria. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello." The climate of Cyprus is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook &Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: HOW NAVVIES LIVE.
div.p: A striking picture of the life lived by a very importation section of the community is given by Dr. Reginald Farrar in a report prepared for the Local Government Board.

While the Brooklands motor-racing track near Weybridge was in course of construction a complaint was received by the Local Government Board as to the failure of the contractors to provide proper accomodation for the navvies engaged in the work, and as to the nuisance to the district arising from this default. Dr. Reginald Farrar was instructed to inquire into the matter. After describing the track and its cost, he says that night and day shifts were at work, that the average wage might be taken at about 24s. a week, and that at the time of his visit at least 1600 men were employed daily on the work. In addition to those in regular employment there were a variable and uncertain number of irregular workers, who work about two days at a time, draw a "sub," and then hang about the public houses, till the money is consumed. There were also casual unemployed labourers and tramps who had come into the neighbourhood on the chance of a job or to sponge on the regular navvies. In all it may be assumed that a floating population of not fewer than 2000 men has been added to the normal population during the month of April.

"I found no provision whatever made by the contractors for the housing or accommodation of the men in their employment. There were not even any shelters to which the men could resort in wet weather. The navvies employed either (1) find lodgings in the neighbourhood and walk or cycle to their work; (2) come in by train from longer or shorter distances; (3) sleep 'rough' for want of accommodation." After dealing with the difficulties of finding lodgings in the neighbourhood, and estimating the number of men who travelled from London at 300 (paying 4s. 6d. each a week for tickets), Dr. Farrar says:

"There remain those who sleep ‘rough' for want of accommodation. The contractor's manager is inclined to minimise this element, alleging that those men sleeping frough' are not genuine navvien, but casual labourers, loafers, and tramps. Having been round the works by night as well as by day, and conversed with scores of men, I can confidently state that many-probably 300 or more of the men regularly employed on the works at the date of my visit were without any proper lodging."

When the public houses were closed Dr. Farrar and two constables" made a search and found the following :-Six men sleeping in straw-yards, in or under the stacks. Seventeen men sleeping in a disused 'cowshed, 24ft. by 12ft. by 7ft. at the eaves. This shed was inside the track. The men were sleeping on the bare ground, without straw or hay for bedding. The available air space was certainly less than 200 cubic feet per head. More than a score of men were lying or sitting round a brazier near a coffee-stall, having no other prospect of shelter for the night. About thirty were sleeping in a dell near the railway line in groups round fires, which they had kindled between the trunks of felled trees. A, casual search revealed three men sleeping among the gorse and heather of Weybridge Common. I cannot doubt but that a careful search would have led to the finding of many more. As was the case in the day-time, the great majority of these homeless men were genuine navvies, regularly working for the contractors."

Dr. Farrar gives the following among his conclusions :— "The proximity of London (nineteen miles) is regarded by the contractors as, to some extent, exonerating them from the responsibility of providing accommodation. Taking all the circumstances into consideration, as enhancing the difficulties of the case, I am still of opinion that the contractors have failed to meet their moral responsibilities towards their workmen and towards the district which they have flooded with such a large number of non-residents. I would suggest that any contractor employing more than a certain number of men on any works might be put under the obligation to inform beforehand the sanitary authority of the district concerned as to the commencement of such works and of their close. The sanitary authority should be under the obligation to notify the Local Government Board, and thus a current register of constructional works might be formed and kept up to date."
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
Suicide.
A Greek barber, living in Sisters Street, age 50 years, committed suicide by throwing himself into the sea.

div.head: Drowing Fatality.
div.p: A native girl, 6 years of age was found drowned in the Mahmoudieh Canal yesterday. The body was transported to the hospital.

div.head: The Slave Trade.
div.p: During the month of August the service for the repression of the slave trade liberated 3 Sudanese at Cairo, 4 at Alexandria, and 2 at Suez.

div.head: Parisian Operatic Company.
div.p: It is announced that an excellent Parisian operatic company has been formed and will shortly leave Paris on a tour to Constantinople, Cairo, . Alexandria, Athens, Smyrna and Salonica.

div.head: Tanzim Department
div.p: The Tanzim Department in Cairo has lately informed owners of badly constructed houses, evincing danger to the public, to start at once in demolishing them within a fixed period, at the expiration of which they will be held responsible if the order is not complied with.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G. P. O.. Alexandria, at 3 10 p.m. on Monday for ordinary correspondence, 2. 10 p.m. for registered correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at noon on Sunday for parcels.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and September 13 900,491 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 486,471 tons were Welsh 119,099 Neweastle, 141,256 Yorkshire, 76,272 Scotch and 77,393 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 834,424.

div.head: The Tour Eiffel.
div.p: Two importants debuts are announced for the Tour Eiffel Music-hall for this evening, namely that of Mlle Delfreda from the Casino de Paris, and a new Spanish dancer, Mlle Carmen Moreno. Of the rest of the troupe we need but say that the applause which greets their nightly efforts is an ample appreciation of their excellence.

div.head: Increased Passage Rates.
div.p: Owing to the increase in the price of coal the Italian General Navigation Co. will increase their passage rates in the 1st and 2nd class by 10% to date from the 15th inst. The company is instituting a new regular monthly line viz : Port Said, Suez, Port Sudan, Massawa, Hodeida, and Djibuti starting from October 12.

div.head: Postal Administration.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has approved the following nominations to the Direction general of the Postal administration. M. Goldstein is appointed chief secretary, M. Fux director of the traffic department, and Salib Claudius inspector general. The post of sub-director general is abolished.

div.head: Nothing Unusual.
div.p: Lord Cromer when ruler of Egypt made himself hateful to all sorts of rascals in that country, but he worked wonders of reform there and left it in more contented frame of mind than it had ever known previous to his arrival. While Lord Salisbury wąs British premier a member of the ministry complained that Lord Cromer had told him to go to the devil. “Dear me” said Salisbury "he tells me that every time he comes to London.”—Cleveland Leader.

div.head: The Right of Transfer.
div.p: Many who are obliged through business to remain sometimes in Alexandria and some. times in Cairo will be pleased to hear that, owing to the unity of administration of the Berlitz Schools the lessons begun at the Alex andria Branch-12 Rue Rosette or at the Carlton Hotel-may be continued without extra charge at the Cairo Branch 1 Sharia Kamel - and vice versa. This practical way permits those who change their residence frequently to pursue their study of English or of any other language without interruption.
[Advt.]

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Ce soir aura lieu la grande fête de nuit au bénéfice de l'école de musique italienne, Alessandro Lamarmora. Cette fête promet d'être très brillante, vu le concours de différentes sociétés italiennes qui y assisteront. L'orchestre Bracàle se fera entendre pendant le diner et jouera ensuite à tour de rôle avec la fanfare Alessandro Lamarmora pendant le spectacle cinématographique,qui commencera à 10 heures précises. Toute la terrasse sera illuminée et magnifiquement décorée.
Messieurs les abonnés sont priés de prendre note que les abonnements seront suspendus.

Entrée P. T. 5. Demain à 11 heures, grand concert sympho. nique, au programme duquel nous voyons figurer la symphonie Op. 36 de Goldmark, qui est donnée pourla première fois, ainsi que la grande fantaisie de Massenet sur l'opéra du Cid. Nous remarquons avec plaisir la peine que se donne Mo Bracale pour nous offrir toujours du nouveau et ce qu'il y a de mieux en musique. Nous sommes certains que les amateurs seront nombreux demain matin, pour apprécier ces deux morceaux de valeur.

div.head: MR BLUNT AND THE CYPRUS CONVENTION.
div.p: REPLY TO "TOBY, M.P.".

Mr. Blunt has sent the following reply to the criticism of his conclusions in his "Secret History of the English Occupation of Egypt" regarding the acquisition of Cyprus by Great Britain in a recent issue of the "Westminster Gazette."

I am glad that Mr. Lucy should have raised the question in your columns of what took place at the Congress of Berlin about the Cyprus Convention in 1878, as it is a point of great historical importance which needs being accurately determined, leading, as it did, to the French aggression on Tunis in 1881, and to much else that has happened since and is happening in North Africa.

It is very possible that, as Mr. Luoy says, there may be a confusion of dates in my account of the quarrel with M, Waddington, as given in my "Secret History of the English Occupation of Egypt," or, rather, in my recollection of the account given me of it in 1879 by Lord Lytton. I have no implicit faith in recollections dating from so far back, nor had I in 1879 begun to keep & political journal. I will look up the dates quoted by Mr. Lucy, and embody the result in a note to the second edition of my History now being got ready.

In the meanwbile it will perhaps help Mr. Lney to a less sceptical attitude if I give you in corroboration, the full text of what is, at any rate, the authentic record of a conversation I had with Count Corti on the same snbject five years later, a conversation set down by me at the time, and which I find recorded in my diary of 1884. I beg Mr. Lucy to observe that the Count, who had been Italian Ambas. sador at the Congress, and who was now, when I met him at Constantinople in 1884, Ambassador to the Sultan, relates of the Cyprus Convention that it had been "broken gently to Waddington before the news was published.” May not this previons divulging at Berlin of the secret Convention reconcile the discrepancy of dates, and leave the story as I have remembered it, if not quite accurately told, substantially true ?

"October 26.--Count Corti came to take us in a steam launch to Therapia. We had luncheon with the Wyndhams, and called on the Noailles [at thě English and French Embassies]. ... On our way back to Constantinople Count Corti entertained us with stories of the Berlin Congress and of Lord Salisbury's antics there. Disraeli and Salisbury has gone there quite on their high horse to curb the territorial ambition of Russia, and the publication of the secret Convention for the acquisition of Cyprus was a great shock to everybody. Salisbury broke it cently to Waddington before the news was published, and Waddington consulted his colleagues, it being generally agreed that there was no middle course between going to war and saying nothing. Il faut la guerre on se taire. But the publication was a great blow to Disraeli, who took to his bed and did not appear for four or five days. Lord Salisbury, however, brazened it out, and came to the Congress with an air of defiance. There was no rupture between him and Waddington, and they remained on apparently friendly terms; but Waddington had his revenge. He was sitting one day with Salisbury, and, the conversation leading that way, Waddington asked what the English Government would say to France taking

Tunis, and Salisbury said he did not see the harm). Whereupon Waddington communicated this to Paris, and on his return the French Ambassador in London was instructed to write to Lord Salisbury reminding him of his words. Thus Salisbury was caught. But,' said Corti, 'if he had known anything of his business he would have declined to answer the note officially and would have pleaded a private conversation.' He did not believe that any arrangement of condominium was come to between Salisbury and Waddington at that time, thongh I told him without mentioning names, of the letter Lytton had shown me. Count Corti is interesting diplomatically, as he has been to more Congresses than any man in Europe."

This is, I think, as good evidence to the main fact, doubted by Mr. Lucy, that it was the Cyprus Convention, not a private Agreement with Russia, that led to the quarrel and compromise about Tunis, as in such very secret affairs is likely to be had. I take this opportunity of saying publicly to all whom it may concern that I shall be really grateful for corrections on first-hand authority of inaccurate statements made in my History, especially if they are sent me in time for the new edition. My object in publishing has been, and is, to establish the truth and nothing but the truth.

div.head: EGYPT AND ITALY.
div.p: THE TRADE TREATY.
We extract the following, relating to the trade between Egypt and South Italy, from the “Diplomatic and Consular Report" for 1906 :

A commercial treaty has been concluded between Italy and Egypt, similar in many respects to those concluded by the latter country with the United Kingdom, Austria. Hungary, Belgium, France, and Germany. This treaty will protect Italian importers from possible vexatious interpretations of the customs laws of Egypt, and will smooth over certain points which in the past have given rise to discussions. The methods of valuation are clearly laid down in the seventh clause, and further on, the law is settled as regards patterns, and the exemption of goods in bond, the importation of arms and reciprocal rights of fishery in territorial waters. The trade of Italy with Egypt is one which is becoming more and more important. In 1900 the imports from Egypt to Italy amounted to 434,2801., and rose in 1904 (the latest year for which there are statistics) to 660,000l.; while Italian exports to Egypt, which in 1900 amounted to 1,200,0001., reached 1,840,0001: in 1904.

Italian exports to Egypt consist principally of wine, olive oil, cordage, cotton 'and silk textiles, raw silk, matches, furniture, paper, sulphur, coloured pottery, flour (to the value of 40,000l. in 1904), macaroni, cut coral and marble. In silk alone the export amounted in 1904 to 320,0001.

The Italian imports from Egypt consist mainly of cotton in its raw state, which from 320,0001. in 1901 rose in 1905 to 600,0001. ; while other imports of less value are tobacco, gum, hides, scrap iron, ivory, mother-of-pearl "and tortoiseshell.

The increase of business to be hoped for from this treaty, combined with the increasing passenger traffic between the two countries, should enable Italy to establish lines of communications which will be highly profitable, and open out the markets of Egypt.

The large number of Europeans who visit Egypt every winter has caused a remarkable increase in the number of bats imported into that country. The total value in 1891 was 8,7721. from all countries, whereas in 1906 the amount reached the sum of 21,0751., or an increase of 12,3031. The trade is in the hands of France, the United Kingdom and Italy, other countries having no considerable share in it. France and the United Kingdom have both doubled their trade, and that of Italy has increased very largely. The values for the three countries are France, 9,317l. ; the United Kingdom, 5,8641. ; and Italy, 2,6521. ; leaving 3,2601. for other countries. British trade is mainly in felt hats and cheap cloth caps; the French in straw hats and boys' caps, for which they have a large sale in the Sondan ; and the Italian in the fine straw hats of Tuscany, especially those for the use of ladies. The greater part of the entire trade is in straw. hats, as the mild climate makes them preferable to the heavier kinds of headcovering.

div.head: THE "OLIVEMOOR."
div.p: Contrary to the hopes expressed in our issue of yesterday the "Olivemoor" has not yet been refloated, and we understand that the damage done to her bottom exceeds the extent at first estimated by those in charge of the salvage operations.

Late last night the "Bergher Wilhelm” left the stranded vessel, the rongh weather not permitting her to continue the necessary operations, and up to the present there is no sign of her returning. The vessel has now been considerably lightened by the pumping operations but in order to float her it will be necessary to raise her at least four feet. In order to do this it will be necessary to discharge a part of the cargo, and this will be done at the earliest moment possible. Unfortunately the weather continues unfavourable, and the extensive damages which the ship has sustained greatly handicaps the salvage operations.

We are pleased to learn that Mr. Grieg, Acting Consul General for Alexandria, has refused to discharge the crew of the “Olivemoor” on the grounds that (1) the vessel has not yet reached harbour, (2) that she is not yet a complete wreck, and that there is every probability that she will be refloated should the weather conditions become more favourable than at present.
The engine-room and stoke-hole are now free of water, and the donkey engine continues to be used for pumping operations.

div.head: ANCIENT UNDERTAKINGS
div.p: In ancient times the great engineering works were costly in human lives. The making of the Red sea canal is said to have involved the loss of no fewer than 120,000 Egyptians. Buckle's examination made him believe the number to have been somewhat exaggerated, but be gives it as still a guide to the enormous waste of human life in those days. The men who kept 2,000 slaves engaged for three years bringing a single stone from Elephantine to the Pyramids did not care a great deal so long as in the twenty years in which one of the pyramids was building there were forthcoming the 860 000 I men required for the work.

div.head: INVESTMENT IN EGYPT.
div.p: SOURCE OF WEALTH.
(Continued.)

While measures were being taken to increase and assure, the water supply, a complete system of drainage—subsoil, surface, and "warping,” according to the nature of the land -was first mapped out and then carried through so that the increased water might be utilized when available without risk of deterioration of the soil by water-logging. Concurrently, and in order to facilitate the transport of produce to market, the several means of communication -railway, agricultural roads, navigable canals and bridges (in place of the old ferries) were improved, a som not far short of a million sterling being annually devoted thereto, while a great stimulus was given to water-borne traffic by the abolition of lock and bridge tolls. Though river competition naturally effects railway receipts, the country as a whole undoubtedly benefits by the dual stream of traffic. Finally, with a view to preventing the exhaustion of the soil by double-cropping, the British authorities have been at great pains to introduce chemical and other artificial manures aforetime unknown to, or at least ignored by, the native farmers, who formerly contented themselves with refuse earth taken from ancient ruined villages. And this does not merely apply to well-to-do farmers, for the Ministry of finance yearly grants advances to the Agricultural Society (in 1907 £50,000 has been already voted) for the purpose of purchasing manures to retail to small farmers. The result of these reasoned improvements has been to treble in the last seven years the value of lands worth from £20 to £25 an acre in 1900 and to double those valued in the same year at from £50 to £60. And if exception is taken to my statement of the case it can only justly be in the form of an assertion that I have understated it. I hold that this rise in the value of agricultural land is not fictitions, but justified by sound, business-like calculation. For instance, take a farm of 100 acres which yielded its owner in 1900 a nett income of £450 ; if we capitalize the value of the land on the basis of a 71% profit the 100 acres were then worth £6,000—or £60 an acre. And inasmuch as in 1907 the same farin yields probably well over £1,000 net income, we find on the same 71% basis, that its capitalized value to-day is over £13,000—or £130 per acre.

The next step in our argument leads us to consider cotton, Egypt's staple product, and it will be clearly shown how it has advanced both in quantity and price, while its distinctive qualitity has been maintained. The reason for confining my remarks to cotton is, roughly speaking, because Egyptian farmers in general look to their cotton crop for their profit; the other produce of their lands—wheat, maize, clover, etc.—being sufficiently valuable to enable the farmer to pay his taxes, his own daily expenses, his labourers, the upkeep of his farm, and the feed of his cattle, plus the purchase of selected seed for the next season.

Even as the value of agricultural land, speaking generally, has doubled throughout Egypt, so also has the cotton crop more than doubled in quantity since the British occupation, having risen from three million cantars (of 99lb. each) in 1887 to seven million cantars in 1907, and it is estimated, when all basin lands shall have been reclaimed that the annual cotton crop may reach to ten million cantars. The price of cotton per cantar has also practically doubled in the last ten years, as in 1896-7 it averaged $9 (£1.18s.) and in 1906-7 $19, or £3 16s. Egypt's cotton crop in 1896-7 fetched a little over £11,000,000 while in 1906-7 it produced close on £27,000,000. That the high price of $19 per cantar still rules is evidenced by the fact that more than one-third of the present (new) crop has already been sold at in fact, over-that figure.

Incidentally, I may mention that of the influx of gold into Egypt to pay for these huge cotton crops an undue proportion remains in the country, and unfortunately it does not all remain in circulation, for the natives hoard gold, and even convert important quantities of gold coins into jewellery. It has been estimated that during the last four years over £15,000,000 of the imported gold has been added to the permanent stock of the country, much of which lies dormant like a miser's store ; and this practice of hoarding, besides being in itself senseless, is undoubtedly a fertile cause of much: crime. The chief hope of the return to circulation of any considerable portion of these hoards lies in the fact that the natives have a mania for buying farm lands, and, as slightly over one eighth of the arable lands in Egypt are still in the hands of foreigners, it is probable that the natives, who do not invest in company shares, will seek to purchase all or part of these foreign holdings, and so the accumulation of gold may be gradually released. That they will so absorb the greater part of the lands now held by aliens I have little doubt, for the prosperous native is not niggardly, and if he wants a plot of land, especially if it adjoins his own farm, he will assuredly make a handsome offer.
(To be continued)

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner "Britannia” sailed from Liverpool last Thursday for Lisbon, Gibraltar, Malta and Alexandria with passengers and a general cargo.

div.head: BONAPARTE IN EGYPT.
div.p: LATE HAJI BROWNE'S BOOK.
(Continued)

"The mere fact that the oppression from which he suffered was consistent with the laws of the land stirred the Englishman to hope for better things, for if he could by any means bring about a change of the laws he could not fail to benefit from it, and that such changes as he desired could be brought about he was convinced. French and Egyptians suffered not from the laws, bat from the abuse of such legal authority as existed. The English, too, might, and did, hope to benefit from the mutual rivalries of the parties and classes that jointly oppressed them. The others had no such resource. And the Englishman's beliet in his ability to rebel, and to rebel successfully, gave him & self reliance and determination that everything denied to the Egyptian and which the French could only employ in the extermination of their tyrants. Other influences were in favour of the peaceful realisation of the Englishman's hopes. He had friends in the classes above him. There were men like Howard and Wilberforce to plead the cause of the prisoner and the slave, like Cobbett, Paine, and Wilkes, to stir the people up to effort, like Burke and Pitt, to preach reform, and yet more potent than all these, like Lindsey and Raikes, the founders of Sunday Schools, who, by teaching the people the value of education, laid the real foundations of the England of to-day. In Egypt there were not, and could not be, such men as these. The Egyptians had, as we have seen, friends and protectors in the Ulema, but friends whose ability to aid them was altogether out of proportion to their willingness, and whose narrow training and insufficient culture unfitted them to cope with the evils they had to face, and which many of them would have honestly have laboured to mend could they but have found a way to do so. Thus all the conditions and circumstances in the three countries tended in different directions—in one, to move the people to peaceful action ; in another to drive them to destructive wrath, and in the third, to lead them to patient submission. For the Englishman and the French, then there were ways of progress--ways encumbered with difficulties and dangers, but with something more than a mere possibility of success to draw them onward-while the Egyptians were on all sides hemmed in by the impossible.”

What strikes us forcibly in this chapter and throughout the book is his constant attitude of excuse for the Egyptian, and here we think the proverb "qui s'excuse s'accuge" partly applies ; for surely the answer is that had the Egyptians really possessed the necessary national characteristics to make a successful nation they undoubtebly must have become one, and the fact of their failure to break away from constant servitude and to take a line of their own must be regarded as proof that they lack and always have lacked the necessary capacity.

Towards the latter end of the book the author jumps incontinently into modern times, and discusses the attitude of the English today. We are surprised that with his fondness for marking down critical episodes and epoch making events he has not included the appointment of the late consul general of Great Britain as at least one, if not the greatest, in Egypt's history; he glides as it were into the English regime and considers what he calls the healthy and unhealthy influences at work. We have not space to discuss these in detail, but among the healthy influences he has bit on what after all is, we think, the solution or rather the explanation of the whole matter which he has so much at heart "the increased acquaintance of the people with European civilisation" and we would add the increased acquaintance of Europeans with Egypt. For the fault, if fault there be, is not all, we think, on one side ; we agree with Haji Browne that the Egyptian race has suffered much in the past ; where east and west have had to meet, and meet violently as they have in Egypt, it is no matter for surprise that there has been friction ; there are many cases where such friction has for centuries existed between a western people and their subjugated neighbours and how much more is it to be expected where there exists the wide divergence of the eastern from the western aspect of lita It is all part of the process of evolution and as such cannot be hurried. It is only by time that sympathy will be bred, and all attempts to increase the sympathy in a legitimate way are welcome ; and of such attempts we think the present work is a genuine one; fair criticism without rancour can do no harın, bat what is needed above all is to be practical, and this is where we claim great merit for the English government of to-day; its sympathy takes a practical form, a form which cannot fail to appeal to any thinking Egyptian. Whether complete sympathy of ideas can ever grow between east and west is a question to which no wise man would give a definite answer ; but one thing is certain, and that is that it is useless to try and hurry things and equally useless to groan over the past, as Haji Browne tende to do. Not that we have not been interested in his portrayal of the attitude of the Egyptians to their western invaders; it is our earnest wish to see both sides of the question and to cultivate that sympathy which alone can make our role in Egypt a perfect success, but we must be excused if we remain at variance on some points of practical politics which we still view from the western standpoint. We confess that we are more inclined to marvel at the progress which the entente of east and west has. made in the last quarter of a century and we look with complete optimism to the continuance of this progress,

It is with deep regret that we have learnt of the sad decease of Haji Browne on the eve of the publication of his work, a work which is well worthy the attention of all who are interested in this problem. For it is the result of a life's work among those of whom he writes and whose point of view he has evidently spared no pains to understand.

His style is apt to be florid in places but he is never dull; in fact we regard the chapter on the siege of Cairo as a very powerful piece of writing. Perhaps he would have done better had be condensed the work a little and written it more in essay form; but these are details compared with the importance of the fact that here we have a genuine effort from & map of western birth and eastern experience to solve the problem of why these two have never yet succeeded in meeting.
*"Bonaparte in Egypt, and the Egyptians of to day," by Haji A. Browno, London : 1. Fisher Union.).

Prince Mohamed Aly yesterday visited the Sidi Abu-el-Abas mosque at Alexandria for the mid-day devotions. The Ras-el-Tin road and the vicinity of the mosque, were decorated for the occasion and a large number of notables . were in attendance. The Prince returns to Cairo this evening.
Mgr. Kyrillos, Catholic Patriarch of Alexandria and Antioch, left yesterday for Cairo, where he will inaugurate the new boys' school in Faggalla Street to-morrow.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: TURKISH TROOPSHIPS.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Suez, September 13.
The Turkish troopship "Assyr" entered the Canal yesterday afterday afternoon with time-expired men, in strict quarantine. Another troopship with reinforcements is expected daily at Port Said.
The pilgrimage to Mecca has now begun, and in comparison large numbers of foreign pilgrims are leaving weekly from Suez for Jeddah.
The S.S. "Ailsa Craig” is now landing a full. cargo of Australian meat at Suez.

div.head: BLUE NILE BRIDGE.
div.p: The contract for the bridge across the Blue Nile between Khartoum and Khartoum North has been signed with the Cleveland Bridge and Engineering Co. of Darlington, England. This is the Company which built the bridge over the Victoria Falls in South Africa, one of the greatest engineering feats of recent years.

Work will commence next December, and the contractors agree to bring the bridge within one year to such a state of completion as to make it fit for passage of trains ; and to complete the work in another year, so that by December 1909, the bridge will be ready for regular traffic.

The contractors also agree, as we learn, in case any of the workmen should be injured while working on the bridge, to pay pensation in accordance with the Works Compensation Act recently passed by Parliament.

There will be a draw, or movable section, on the Halfaya side, which will be used for allowing ships to pass. This will be worked by electricity. *The total cost of the bridge will amount to £230,000. The balance of the $450,000, Appropriated for this project, will probably be expended on the approaches of the bridge.

div.head: THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
div.p: ARMISTICE GRANTED.
HEAVY ARAB LOSSES.
CASABLANCA, September 13.

The Chaouias tribes sent a deputation to General Drude offering surrender. The General Granted a suspension of hostilities until tomorrow, and said that it would be useless for the deputies to return unless all his conditions were accepted. (Havas)
CASABLANCA, September 13.

The stragglers who surrendered declare that the Araba lost 300 killed and many wounded, but this is probably an exaggeration. There are two other camps in the vicinity: it is expected that General Drude will next attack these. (Reuter)

div.head: THE “LUSITANIA'S" VOYAGE.
div.p: NEW RECORD CREATED.
LONDON, September 13.

Unprecedented interest is being taken in the voyage of the "Lusitania" on both sides of the Atlantic. Scores of marconigrams are published showing the daily progress of the vessel. She is expected to smash the Queenstown record. Extraordinary preparations are being made to welcome her on arrival in New-York. (Reuter)
NEW YORK, September 13.

The "Lusitania' has arrived. She completed the voyage in 5 days and 54 minutes. She was twice delayed by fog. Her average speed vas. 23.01 knots, which beats all westward maiden voyage records ; but the average speed is below the westward records of the "Deutschland" and "Kronprinz Wilhelm" of 23:15 and 23:09 knots respectively. In view of the delays she is confidently anticipated to prove the featent liner afloat. A scene of great enthusiasm was witnessed on her arrival. (Reuter)

div.head: TSAR LIBERATOR MONUMENT
div.p: SOFIA, September 13.

A monument to the Tear liberator has been unveiled here with ceremony in the presence of the Grand Duke and Duchess Vladimir, members of the diplomatic corps, and Russian Generals of the Russo-Turkish war. (Reuter)

div.head: SIR JOHN LANE HARRINGTON
div.p: LONDON, September 13.
Sir John Lane Harrington will return to Addis Abeda in the Autumn (Reuter)

div.head: NEW AIRSHIP TRIALS.
div.p: LONDON, September, 13.

Le "Daily Mail” states that the military authorities have established a station among the remote Athol mountains in Scotland, where the experiments with the new aeroplane will be conducted with the strictest secrecy. (Reuter)

div.head: THE BULGARIAN RAIDS.
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE, September 13.

The commander of the troop at Seres has complained to the Porte of the small number of troops at his disposal, which, he says, does not permit of his taking vigorous steps against the numerous Bulgarian bands infecting the district (Reuter)

div.head: POLE EXPEDITION.
div.p: New YORK, September 13.

Mr. Wellman and two companions started in the direction of the Pole in a dirigible balloon on the 2nd instant. The start was most successful, but a northerly wind soon drove the balloon back over Spitbergen where it alighted. The expedition has returned to to Tromsoe. (Reuter)

div.head: THE “STANDART” ACCIDENT.
div.p: HELSINGFORS, September 13.
Owing to the accident to the yacht "Standart," the Russian Sovereigns are continuing their cruise on board the "Alexandria." (II.)

div.head: GERMAN COTTON SYNDICATE
div.p: BERLIN, September 13.

A German Victoria Nyanza steamship company is being formed to carry on cotton growing, and to place small steamers on the lake to act as feeders to large British steamers. The Company is sending out at first a 15-ton steamer launch. (Reuter)

div.head: A MURDERER PARDONED.
div.p: PARIS, September 13.
The President of the Republic has pardoned Soleillant, the murderer of the child Erbélding. (Havas)

div.head: MR. MALMUSI'S RESIGNATION
div.p: CONTRADICTED.
PARIS, September 13.
A telegram from Rome to the "Eelair” says that Mr. Malmusi will keep his post. (Havas)

div.head: HOME RACING.
div.p: DONCASTER CUP.
London, September 13.
Velocity ; 2 Bridge of Canny; 3 White Knight. Betting : 7 to 1 Velocity : 6 to 1 Bridge of Carny : 4 to 6 White Knight. Won by 6 lengths. Three quarters of a neck between second and third. (Reuter)

div.head: MODERN EGYPT
div.p: A correspondent writes to the “Rochester Post Express" :—

I find Egypt changing in character. The Mohammedans are being corrupted by the Christians, and the simple living taught by the Koran, whereby the believer abstains from strong drink and other vices, has become infected with the gay and giddy pleasures of the French. Cairo, the city of the Arabian nights, and the Mohammedan call to prayer is now mingled with the bacchanalian songs of the cafe chantants. In many cases the system of the harem is being exchanged for something worse. The average Mohammedan has but one wife, but in many cases he has a sweetheart in a house around the corner.

The ghouls of modern science are robbing the graves of those who made the pyramids. A telephone line has been stretched out of Cairo almost to the ear of the Sphinx, and there is a hotel at the base of the Pyramid of Cheops, where English men and women drink brandy and soda between the games of tennis and golf.

The Egyptof to-day isa land of mighty hotels and multitudinous tourists. Our consul-general estimates that Americans alone spend almost four million dollars here every winter, and the English, French and Germans spend almost as much. He estimates that there are ten thousand Americans who visit the Nile valley every season and that it costs each one of them something like $10 per day for an average stay of two months.

The native are growing rich and the Mohammedans are for the first time in the history of Egypt, piling up money. They are investing their surplus in real estate, and it is this that has done mach to swell all land values.

Egypt is still a country of the Egyptians, notwithstanding the government of the English and the influx of the foreigners. It has now about 10,000,000 people and of these 9,800,000 are either Arabs or descendants of the original Egyptians. The most of them are Mohammedang, although there are all told something like 600,000 Copts. The Copts are the descendants of the ancient Egyptians. They have a rude kind of Christianity, and are, as a body, better educated and wealthier than the Muhammedans. They are noted as clerks and accountants and are also fine workmen in gold and silver and in other such trades. They are money makers and money savers and I under stand that many of them, especially in upper Egypt, are now making fortunes. The pure Mohammedans do not as a rule go into banking or money-lending. That is against the Koran and they invest most of their savings in lands.

The foreign population of Egypt is less than 200,000. The greater part of it is to be found in Alexandria and Cairo, and in the other towns of the Nile valley, as well as in Suez and Port Said. There are more Greeks than any other. The Greeks have been exploiting the Egyptians and the Nile valley for more than 2,000 years and they are to-day the sharpest, shrewdest and most unscrupulous business men in it.

div.head: A PARLIAMENT IN TURBANS
div.p: "Whatever the Almighty has ordained, let it happen," said the Persian Prezpier, when his coachman begged him to leave Parliament by a back exit to avoid strange people near the other gate. So he went the usual way, and was shot dead by a money-changer (Aug. 31, 1907).

This dramatic incident calls attention to the romance of modern Persia—the establishment of a Parliament among the wearers of turbans—a constitutional movement which the Times" says has "transformed the whole sitnation in the country."

"Few events could afford more suggestive food for meditation to the practical statesman and to the speculative student of history in the making," adds the Times" in a most informative article. "The magnitude and the energy of the movement in the northern provinces are unquestionable. It has achieved startling results, almost without violence and by the mere menace of popular action. In a land which has known no form of rule but the uncontrolled dominion of the great King' since the days of Cyrus and of Xerxes, it has established an elected Parliament with very wide constitutional powers, which is conscious and jealous of its rights. Before that movement the greatest princes and potentates of the kingdom have bowed low.

"The Ain-ed-Dowleh, who was governing Persia with boundless authority and relentless severity last year, fell without a struggle at its summons. The Zill-es-Sultan, an unele of the Shah, whose commands were law over almost half the kingdom for nearly forty years, has been dismissed from the Governorship of Isfahan on its demand. Great provincial chiefs like Asaf ed-Dowleh, the Governor of Khorassan, and a host of high officials and courtiers, have been forced to surrender their posts and their emoluments. Even the Belgian heads of the new Customs service, who enjoyed the special countenance and support of Russia, have had to resign their lucrative and important offices in deference to the cry of the people. The Shah himself, who at first showed reluctance to confirm the Constitution granted by his dying father, quickly found it expedient to ratify that document in the amplest and most solemn form. Yet more significant, perhaps, is the way in which the powerful and highly organised religions chiefs of the nation, the Mujtehids and Mollahs, are constrained to continue at the head of a movement which they have come to regard with suspicion and with fear, lest opposition to it should shatter their spiritual authority.

"But great though the power which has wrought these changes must manifestly be, its nature and extent and the degree of permanence which it may possess are for the present incalculable to Western observers. Behind it there must be a certain number of men possessed of considerable faculty for organisation. These men did not originate the revolution, though doubtless they had been preparing for it. The late Shah offered no resistance to their demands, and the first Persian Parliament actually met for the despatch of business in the autumn, and at once became supreme in the State.

"More remarkable even than the revolution which the reformers have effected in the central Government have been the changes which they have accomplished in local administration Throughout the north-eastern provinces, and in many towns in other provinces, they have not only driven out the former Governors, whose sole occupation was to amass riches by extortion and corruption, but they have achieved the far more difficult and creditable feat of creating a comparatively efficient local government instead of the old despotism. In many places the new authorities have their own police, and pay them, & precaution against oppression which the former Governors and their deputies never took. Order is better preserved and the property and persons of strangers as well as of natives are safer, where the new authorities command, than where the survivors of the old system yet remain. The machinery of the movement undoubtedly consists of a network of secret societies. Little, naturally, is known of the numbers and the constitution of these bodies, but they are said to have their headquarters, with supplies of arms and of bombs ready, across the Russian border, and it is certainly through them that the movement is spread and directed.

"The general objects which the reformers have in view are the preservation of Persia from foreign control, and the establishment of some tolerable form of domestic government and administration. It may be doubted, however, whether even the most enlightened of them have any clear ideas as to how these ends should be attained. The proceedings of the Parliament have shown that the leaders of the popular party have almost as little grasp of the real facts of the world as ordinary Chinamen. Unlike the local administrations, the Legislature has not displayed any capacity for constructive legislation, and it has not hitherto produced any statesman of command. ing ability and character. These are serious shortcomings in a nation which aspires to self government.

"Over against the reformers stand the forces of reaction. They are necessarily considerable in a country like Persia. It is no secret that the reigning Shah, Mohammed Ali, tolerates the Constitution only because he is afraid to attack it without the assurance of foreign support. About him are gathered all the classes which grew rich upon the spoils of office under the old régime.

"The Parliament, not unnaturally, has disappointed the extravagant hopes which its creation excited. Some of its own members are complaining that its labours have produced nothing but anarchy, and it has failed utterly and conspicuously when tried by that great

touchstone of statesmanship, the management of finance, Ita bagno money, and it has no practicable plan für getting money. The general situation is manifestly unstable, and the risks to Europeans, which an unstable situation always involves in Mohamedan countries, are aggravated by some special features of the position in Persia. The frequent resignations of Ministers and the invasion of Persian territory by Turkish troops cannot but increase the general unrest. The position is plainly critical, and it imposes upon the Powers immediately concerned the obligation of watchfulness, judgment, and firm action in common, in order to avert the danger of very serious complications. Events in Persia may clearly at any moment tax the resources of the friendliest diplomacy."
It was because the Persian Premier was believed to be a traitor to the Reform movement that he was shot-by a man who, having done the deed, shot himself.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton. Grâce à la persistance de nos haussiers dans leurs maneuvres, pour commencer, et à la surprise du Rapport du Bureau d'agriculture ensuite, le marché a changé d'allure et de tendance à trois reprises différentes pendant la semaine qui vient de finir. Cela n'a pas nui pour sûr à l'activité des affaires ; tout au contraire, à chaque revirement la lutte a été plus vive et cela a toujours mis de l'entrain. Quoiqu'au fond ce que nous venons de dire soit relatif, on peut quand même se déclarer satisfait des évènements à ce point de vue. Par contre, pour ce qui est des prix, le cas est tout altre, étant donné que le résumé de nos faits et gestes ou pour mieux dire de toutes nos Huctuations consiste en une baisse de 25/32 du point maximum atteint dans le courant de la semaine et de 7/16 de tallari depuis vendredi dernier.

Pour ceux qui doutaient de la faiblesse de notre marché et du peu d'importance du groupe haussier qui avait fini par croire qu'il était réel. lement en état de dominer et de mener les choses à sa façon, la preuve est désormais taite et il ne reste qu'à espérer qu'une fois pour toutes la petite spéculation se convaincra que quand l'édifice pêche par la base, les cris seuls ne suffisent pas pour faire monter les prix et les consolider.

Il peut y avoir en un moment de griserie, ce qui est toujours pardonnable ; mais, ceci admis, nous aimons à croire que le reste du temps il ne s'est agi que de maneuvres ayant pour but de faciliter la besogne aux copains qui auraient été chargés de passer les paquets à d'autres. Dans tous les cas, cette façon d'agir serait plus intelligente que celle consistant à vouloir, en cinq ou six personnes, commander un marché avec toute une combinaison de circonstances adverses comme celles que nous avons enes!

Et ces circonstances ont été nombreuses, soit, en premier lieu, le rapport du Burean d'Agriculture de Washington avec la baisse qui en a été la conséquence et qui constitue un véritable coup de massie ; puis, le développement rapide des arrivages chez nous, ne rencontrant que des acheteurs peu disposés à tout absorber, même avec les concessions continuelles consenties par les vendeurs; ensuite, l'abstention presque toujours absolue de la filature à toucherà tout ce qui est embarquement éloigné et finalement, les avis de plus en plus favorables au sujet de notre récolte. Avec tous ces atouts pour la baisse, ce serait une véritable aberration que de penser seulement que l'on peut faire la hausse ou tout simplement maintenir les cours

Et puis, franchement, on ne saurait s'expliquer cet entêtement à vouloir endiguer le courant : du moment que la baisse est inévitable, pourquoi ne pas la laisser se produire dès le début de la campagne, pour acheter après dans des conditions qui vous permettront de spéculer avec moins de risques et vous donneront plus de chances de profiter d'une amélioration éventuelle , la suite d'un changement quelconque dans l'orientation du marché ?
Mais assez de réflexions et de conseils qui pe nous sont nullement demandés et revenons à la revue du marché.

La séance de samedi, sans le moindre encouragement réel, ni du dehors, ni local, a été très ferme et c'est en hausse de 7/32 de tallari que les cours ont fini par s'inscrire. Dans l'attente du Bureau qui devait arriver le 9 au soir, les vendenrs montraient une réserve excessive et naturellement cette attitude a fait le jeu des haussiers.

Lundi, sur le bruit controuvé d'ailleurs, que des affaires importantes avaient été faites avec la filature et sur quelques pronostics de 68 a 70 pour le Burean attendu, il y a eu accentuation de la hausse jusqu'à 20 15/32, mais la tenue du marché du disponible ayant été des plus faibles, quelques ventes vers clôture ont fini par être faites pour compte de nos expor. tateurs; ce qui nous a fait réactionner de 18 de tallari.

Jusques-là il n'y avait apres tout rien d'ex traordinaire, et en réalité ce n'est que le lendemain que les évènements ont commencé à se dessiner. En effet, le Rapport du Bureau d'Agriculture avec ses 72 7/10 comme condition de la plante et la première baisse d'une trentaine de points qu'il a produite sur les marchés américains a fini par saper la situation et à partir Jn dit moment la fai blesse n'a fait. que dominer en plein, pour nous mener tout droit au cours de 19 11/16 pour le Novembre, anquel la semaine s'est terminée.

La baisse dans ces conditions n'est pas complètement en rapport avec celle subie par les américains, mais une fraction de plus on de moins n'est pas de conséqnence quand on est engagé dans la voie voulue, sur tout que, en général, on commence à se reudre compte de ce que peuvent nous valoir la continuation de la gêne monétaire, l'anxiété du cultivatenr à vouloir vendre et l'importance de notre récolte. Certes, celle-ci n'est pas encore en poche, mais quand on n'entend plus discuter que sur un seul point, à savoir si nous aurons 7 1/2 ou 8 millions de Cantars, et que ces informations nous viennent de l'intérieur, bien malgré soi on se laisse influencer.
Il y a dans ceci une menace de surproduetion qui sera d'un grand poids dans la question de la différence éventuelle entre américain et égyptien et ce point n'est pas à perdre de vue.

Les reports sur Janvier et Mars n'ont plus augmenté, mais nos exportateurs ne désespèrent pas de voir la spéculation lenr offrir un peu plus tard cette source appréciable de bénéfices, dont ils ont si bien profité ces dernières années.

On a fini par se rendre compte sur notre place que nous avons été bel et bien bluffés par les informations journalières d'Amérique qui n'ont fait que nous annoncer désastre sur désastre à cause de la sécher esse pour voir le

div.head: In Spring-Time Many People Need a Good Tonic.

p.hi: Pe-ru-na, a Standard Tonic the World Over.

div.p: From the bracing rigors of winter to the balmy warmth of spring-time is a climatic change that affects every one more or less. A great multitude of people, however, are so affected by the change as to require medical assistance.

If such people neglect to take a good tonic that will safely tide them over the trying weather of early spring, the system is weakened, the blood over loaded with effete materials of the winter season and the victim is rendered an easy prey to acute ailments.

It has been the universal experience of mankind that a spring tonio of some sort is necessary. All kinds of remedies, herbal and mineral, have been used. There is usually great uncertainty as to the operation of the average spring tonic.

Peruna, on the other hand, has been in use for so many years and in such a variety of climates and by such a multitude of people that its beneficial operation for spring ailments has become a practical certainty. Poruna can be relied upon as a spring tonio. It cleanses the blood by correcting the digestion, which is the source of good blood.
Mrs. R. Boyer Writes From 1491 Sherman Ave., Evanston, Ill., Concerning Pe-ru-na. Read Her Letter Below.

"Last spring I became rua down from the serious effects of lingering cold and several complications united in palling me down.
"I could neither eat nor sleep well, and lost flesh and spirit.
"I finally tried Peruna and it did wonders for me.
"In two weeks I was like another person and in s month I felt better than I ever had before.
"I thank Peruna for new life and strength."

"Six months ago my wife's health was very much run down, lacking vigor and suffering with pains in her head and back.

"A friend advised her to try Peruna, which she did with most satisfactory 3 results. In a few weeks she was completely restored to her usual vigor, and Is now happy, well and strong, thanks to Peruna.
I have tried Peruna myself when tired and overworked and in every instance I have felt better within a day or two."

"Every spring and fall, for eleven years, I have been troubled with tarrh in my throat and nose and hoarseness.
"I am pleased to state that at last I found a medicine, Peruna, from which I received great benefit, and I will hereafter use and recommend it. "I always keep it in my house in case of sickness.
“I recommend your medicine to all my friends and every sufferer an excellent medicine."
Mr. C. A. Landgrabe, Box 25, Coalburg, Ohio, Gives His Experience With Peruna. Read His Letter Below.
"I had treen a slight sufferer for a number of years, but paid little attention to it until the spring of this year when my suffering became very severe.
"I had pain in the head, back, liver, chost and other parts of my body, besides indigestion which caused me much trouble.

"Alter using the first bottle of Peruna, I felt relief. I continued to use it until I had taken four bottles, when I felt entirely cured. I recommend Peruna to others."
Mr. E. Arnold, Westerly, R. I., writes:

“I wish to any & good word for your valuable remedy, Pernde. I have taken many kinds of medicine during my life, bnt find that Peruna stands ahead of all. It aids digestion, promotes sleep quiets the nervous system, strengthens the throat and vocal organs. I have used it for catarrh and to break of sudden colds which is the best of all.

"I contracted a severe cold once which ended in pleurisy and loft me weak, and every change of weather would bring a return of old pains. Peruna now van iahon all pain I cannot praise It enough. I told all my friends that it is the best medicine used for the ills of life. If any word of mine will lead others to try it, you are at liberty to use my testimonial in any form."
Mr. B. F. Sellers, 8384 Olive street, St. Louis, Mo., writes:

"Any man in my profession often has to spend the whole night with a tremendous strain on his respiratory organs. I have time and again gone hope so worn out that I could neither eat nor sleep, and a number of my colleagues have been in the same condition.

"But Peruna has changed this. I found that after using a bottle or two my system was greatly invigorated with new life and force, and I can now fortify my system to endure a greater strain than was ever possible before. Peruna certainly is very necessary to me, and me in splendid health,"

I could not eat nor sleep nor work any at all, but was in bed nearly all the time, and was almost a skeleton I was so poor. Now I can eat anything I want and it doesn't hurt me, and I can sleep all night long and get up and work all day. I don't have any nervous-ness now, but am happy all the day long. I sing the praises of Peruna wherever I go, and I believe it saved my life. I could not have lived through the summer in the condition I was in.

I tried your Peruna, and I felt better from the start, I took about five bottles of Peruna and the awful headache and nervousness was gone. tout se résumer en un recul de 2 points en tout dans la condition de la plante !! On dit que New-York est toujours haussier et que c'est New-Orleans qui vend. Mais il nous semble que le fait que c'est le Sud qui est le vendeur est bien plus significatif que si c'étaient les non professionnels de New York qui se mettaient à la baisse. Cela ne veut pas dire assurément que la récolte ne court plus aucun danger, car elle est en retard, mais en somme c'est toujours un indice favorable.

Notre marché du disponible a absolument manqué d'entrain et au fond ce sont les cotons nouveaux de la Hante-Fgypte qui ont alimenté les affaires. Il est cependant de fait que ce n'est qu'en se montrant de facile composition sur la question du prix, que les vendeurs sont parvenus à placer ce qui était destiné an marché.
Comme cote, officiellement le Mit Affifia subi une réduction de 1/2 tallari, tandis que pour les provenances Haute- Egypte elle a été de 5/8.

De la Basse Bgypte, il n'y a en que quelques balles jusqu'ici et le dernier cours pratiqué a este de 21 1.8 pour un lotin de 7 balles de Tantah. La marchandise de Guizeh a obtenu jusqu'à 21 tallaris. Tout cela ne forme pas base.
Les exportations de la semaine ont fini par dépasser quelque peu les prévisions avec leur total de 6500 halles, contre 3700 l'année dernière.

Pour la semaine prochaine, les choses s'annoncent mal comme première journée, mais on ne saurait rien dire, d'autant plus que l'importance de nos embarquements et d'une façon générale au début de la campagne dépendent beaucoup des nouvelles affaires qui se font chaque jour pour expédition immédiate.
L'année dernière, le chiffre était de 4700 balles.
Liverpool a été peu actif pour les Egyptiens disponibles avec ses ventes de 100 à 200 balles par jour.
Quant aux prix, la baisse relevée pour la semaine est de 3/16 pour le spot qui est coté à 10 1/2 et de 16/64 pour le Novembre, renseigné ce soir à 10 17/64.
Il y a eu aussi moins d'affaires sur le disponible américain, mais la rapidité de la baisse qui a surpris les acheteurs est peut-être cause de leur réserve.

En tous cas,pour ce qui est des prix, la baisse est sensible, car, aux cours de 7.10 pour le spot, de 6.44 pour l’octobre novembre et de 6.38 pour le janvier-février, elle s'élève respectivement à 41,42 et 38 points de baisse.

Les arrivages sont bons en eux-mêmes et bien supérieurs à ceux de l'année dernière, mais il y a des besoins, tant pour l'exportation que pour les huileries de notre place et tout ce qui se présente au marché est immédiatement enlevé à des prix soutenus. La dernière cote du disponible a été de P.T. 79 1/2.

En contrats, il n'y a que des affaires rares et intermittentes mais les prix sont restés constamment soutenus, sauf aujourd'hui où ils ont fini par fléchir à P.T. 70 3/4 à cause de Hull surtout. Dans tous les cas, la spéculation ne semble guère avoir d'intérêts dans l'article.
L'Angleterre commence à acheter de nos graines un peu plus libéralement. Les derniers prix payés par Hull sont de £ 7 17/6 pour septembre, £ 7 5/- à 7 7/6 pour octobre et £ 7 1/3 pour les 3 mois.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie le 13 Septembre.

En dépit de la réduction du taux privé d'escompte en Angleterre à 4 % et de la fermeté des valeurs égyptiennes au Stock Exchange, où la National Bank a même gagné 1/8 à 20 3/8, ici nous avons eu mardi un marché si déprimé et si nul comme affaires qu'il ent été préférable de chômer, comme la veille, à l'occasion du Jour de l'An Israélite. Une partie de la cote a subi un recul appréciable. Les rares transactions, d'ailleurs sans importance, qui ont été effectuées, se sont limitées aux National Bank, Agricole, Ritz, Urbaine, Nungovich et Port Said Salt.

La tenue du lendemain qu'on attendait pour juger de la tendance a été franchement mauvaise. Plus faibles, plus déprimées, les valeurs n'ont donné lieu qu'à des transactions insignifiantes et clairsemées.
Hier l'aspect est resté sensiblement le même. A signaler seulement un peu plus de tapage.

Aujourd'hui enfin, sans pouvoir dire que la séance ait été brillante, on a pu cependant constater une certaine amélioration, sinon dans la cote dont les fluctuations sont assez inégales, au moins dans le volume des transactions qui a été un peu plus considé. rable. On en angure bien pour la semaine prochaine.
Sur l'ensemble des valeurs inscrites à la cote officielle de la Bourse d'Alexandrie 9 seulement sont en hausse et 17 en baisse, le plus grand nombre demeurant stationnaire aux cours antérieurs.

Parmi les fluctuations les plus sensibles, il faut signaler : à la hausse, la Delta Light qui gagne 5/16 à 9 3/4 et à la baisse, la Deferred Delta qui perd 1/2 livre à 8, l'Urbaine 5/16 à 3 1/32 vendeurs, et l'Auto Transport 1/2 livre à 3 3/4.

L'Agricole progresse de 8 à 8 1/16, la National Bank de 20 à 20 3/16, les Tramways d'Alexandrie de 143 à 143 1/2 acheteurs les Privilégiées et de 300 à 301 les Dividendes, les Markets de 27/6 à 27/9, la Banque d'Athènes de 109 à 110, les Estates de 5/8 à 21/32 et l'Aboukir de 27/- à 27/6.

D'autre part, l'Alexandria Water rétrograde de 11 3,8 à 11 1/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire de 203 à 200, la Salt and Soda de 18/9 à 18/6, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 301 à 300 l'ancienne et de 254 1/2 à 253 1/2 la nouvelle, la Cassa di Sconto de 39 à 38, la Delta Land de 1 3/4 à 1 11/16, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 21/- à 20/6, la Land Bank de 7 1/4 à 7 1/8, la Building Lands de 2 3/16 à 2, l'Union Foncière de 4 1/2 à 4 5/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 à 4, la Port Said Salt de 14 à 13/9, et les Ritz Hotels de 5/8 à 1/2.

Au cours de la huitaine il a été vendu aux enchères publiques 100 Estates à 21/32, 50 Delta Light à 9 9/16, 25 Anglo-American Nile à 2, 3375 Ritz Hotels à 1/2, 60 actious nouvelles de la Société des Immeubles de la rue Chérif à 4 1/8 et 75 actions anciennes Cassa di Sconto à 38 1/4. C'est à ces exécutions, ainsi qu'aux réalisations et liquidations forcées qu'il faut attribuer en partie la fai. blesse du marché. La cherté du numéraire y est également pour beaucoup : les banques font payer de 7 à 9% d'intérêt et la plupart d'entre elles, à la clôture d'un compte, D'acceptent pas de le renouveler. En général nos établissements de crédit ne consentent des avances qu'à une élite peu nombreuse de clients. Seul ou à peu près le Crédit Lyonnais onvre des comptes courants avec une marge de 40 %, mais uniquernent pour les titres de premier ordre, tels que l'Agricole, la National Bank. la Delta Light, et la Daïra. Nous sommes, en effet, à la veille de la récolte cotonnière et à cette époque on fait argent de toat pour faire face aux nécessités du moment, Dans ces conditions il n'y a guère à espérer avant l'hiver l'afflux de capitaux dont notre corbeille des valeurs a un si pressant besoin pour se remettre à flot. Quant à savoir si le numéraire acquis au pays par la récolte suffira pour rétablir l'équilibre ébranlé, on est généralement pour l'affirmative, à condition que le coton se maintienne à de bons prix : on est déjà fixé sur l'abondance de la récolte, qui sera sensiblement supérieure à celle déjà exceptionnelle de l'année dernière ; quant a la question du prix, elle dépend beaucoup de la récolte aux Etats-Unis, de l'absence en Amérique des cotons fins et de la demande de la filature.
En Angleterre on est favorablement impressionné par les mesures du Trésor AméI ricain prises en vue de prévenir une crise

en automne. Jusqu'ici on ne signale aucune demande de ce côté-là et il n'y en a pas en perspective pour an avenir rapproché. Quand on pense que l'année dernière a pareille date l'Angleterre a da fournir à l'Amérique plus de 3 millions de livres sterling, on ne peut qu'être rassuré cette année-ci, où l'Egypte sera presque seule à puiser dans ses coffres. La lenteur avec laquelle la réserve de la Banque d'Angleterre augmente, bien que son tanx d'escompte soit de 1/2 % plus élevé que celui du taux privé, est cependant surprenante : Cette réserve, en effet, n'est que de 1 1/4 % supérieure à celle de vendredi dernier, soit 51 1/4 contre 50 %. Il parait que les rentrées sont à peu près nulles.

L'allure déprimée de notre marché, habitué depuis quelques semaines à suivre les places dirigeantes, est d'autant plas anormale que les valeurs égyptiennes, si elles n'ont pas donné lieu en Europe à un fort monvement d'affaires, ont été pourtant très soutenues. La plupart même sont en hausse: la Daïra, la National Bank et la Delta Light bénéficient d'une avance de 1 8 aux cours respectifs de 12 7/8,20 3/8 et 9 3/4; l’Agricole est ferme à 8 1/4;l'Unifiée progresse de 101 1/4 à 101 3/4 ; l'action de Suez se relève de 4515 # 4547, l'action Crédit Foncier Égyptien de 685 à 688, et la Land Bank de 184 à 186 ; seul le Cr dit Franco-Eyyptien Aléchit de 107. 50 à 106. D'autre part, le Con solidé Anglais gagne 3/4 de livre à 82 1/2 et la Rente Française 48 points à 94.80. Le taux privé d'escompte s'inscrit en baisse de 1/8 à 4 %.

On discute beaucoup en ce moment sur l'encaisse des banques locales. Les uns prétendent qu'elle est excessivement réduite et les autres au contraire qu'elle est exceptionnellement abondante. Nous croyons pouvoir dire qu'elle est en tous cas suffisante pour les besoins actuels. Le fait est qu'au moment de la crise nos établissements de crédit ont importé une forte quantité de numéraire, pour aug. menter précisément leurs encaisses menscées par la panique. Depuis, porrno point se trouver prises au dépourva en cas de retour de circonstances analogues, elles ont du restreindre leurs avances. Ce qui montre que leurs disponibilités existantes ne sont pas épuisées, c'est qu'elles n'ont pas importé d'or pendant le mois d'Aont. Plusieurs même ont en réserve un stock poor le commencement de la récolte cotonnière. Les sommes nécessaires pour financer celle-ci seront d'ailleurs obtenues sans obstacles en Europe au moment voulu, c'est-àdire vers la fin septembre. La seule difficulté avec laquelle on ait à compter est l'acquisition directe du fellah, qui ne consent à se dessaisir de son coton que contre espèces sonnantes. Le drainage opéré par cette habitude est pour beaucoup dans la disette automnale d'or dont souffre périodiquement notre marché.
Des diverses observations que nous venons de faire, il est facile de tirer la conclusion sur l'allure probable da marché des valeurs : du-

rant un avenir plus ou moins rapproché il p'y & pas à espérer d'amélioration appréciable dans la situation monétaire locale et par conséquent, si une hausse potable se produit, elle ne pourra Gtre attribuée à l'afflux de numéraite attendu. D'autre part, les bas prix actuels ne sont guère susceptibles d'une dépréciation, d'autant plus que la crise proprement dite est plutôt sur son déclin. Les probabilités sont donc pour un état stationnaire jusqu'à ce que le paiement de la récolte cotonnière ait revivifié le pays par la circulation d'or qui lui manque.

Dans l'intérieur les achats de terrains continuent. Ainsi, la Sidi Salem vient de vendre encore 60 feddans de sa propriété à raison de 100 livres le feddan. On voit par là que les terrains de culture n'ont pas été atteints par la crise.

Il n'en est pas de même pour les terrains à bâtir situés dans les banlieues du Caire et d'Alexandrie. Ceux-ci ont été approximativement ramenés à leurs prix antérieurs et les cours des titres de sociétés qui ont fait leurs acquisitions au moment de l'emballement sont évidemment baissé en proportion.

Hier a eu lien la troisième assemblée de la Bourse and Banling. Les actionnaires ont vivement protesté contre une liquidation amiable de la société et, un vote de blame ayant été émis contre le conseil, celui-ci a démissionné en masse; mesure d'ailleurs tar dive puisque aussi bien les actiomaires ont suspendu ses pouvoirs. Une commission, composée de MM. S. Pappo, J. Aghion et A. Nahman, a été nommée pour vérifier les comptes et le bilan ; elle. soumettra ses observations à une 4me assemblée des actionnaires qui aura lieu le 24 courant, date, à laquelle la société, se trouve précisément assignée en état de faillite par la Banque de Salonique, pour un effet impayé d'environ 6000 livres. Nous sommes étonnés que les actionnaires n'aient pas encore intenté de pour suites contre les administrateurs qui etant solvables et pleinement responsables devront. rembourser le capital.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p: "INVESTMENTS" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the

SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account", "The Advantages of 'Call Options"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities"; "How to Invest in Mines" ; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments"; "General Principles for Investors"; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonia) Building Land : Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE
LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Veodredi 13 Septembre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est resté invarié à 4 pour cent. · Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé hier de 1 à 82 1. L'Unifiée a gardé son cours de la veille à 101. La National Bank et l'Agricole ont été sontenues & 20 et 8 respectivement. La Daïra a été ferme à 12 ), de même que la Delta Light à 94.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagné 1 franc à 688, la Banque d'Athènes 1 franc à 113 et les Lots Turcs 1 franc à 166.

Ici, les velléités d'amélioration qu'avait montrées en clôture le marché hier, n'ont malheureusement pas persisté et la lourdeur a prédominé durant toute la séance. Malgré les affaires peu nombreuses et l'abondance des réalisations, la plupart des cours se sont maintenus avec assez d'aisance et ceux qui ont rétrogradé ne l'ont fait qne très légèrement. Quelques valeurs influencées par les cours de Londres ont même bénéficié de quelques fractions.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank hausse à 20 1/8-3/16. L'Agricole est calme à 8 1/16. La Cassa di Sconto se relève à 37-38. La Banque d'Athènes réagit à 108-109.

La Delta Light progresse à 9 13/16. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire se tassent à 196-197 et la Daïra Sanieh à 12 5/8. Les obligations anciennes du Crédit Foncier reculent à 300. L'obligation Béhéra est demandée à 4 1/16. La fondateur Allotment revient à P.T. 60. L'Enterprise and Development fléchit à 8 9/16 tandis que sa fondateur continue à hausser à 10 1. La Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux maintient son cours de 2 tandis que la part est un peu moins soutenue à 42-43. L'Union Foncière retombe à 4 5/16.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, lez Baehler, moins fermes, s'inscrivent à 6-6 1/16. Les Ritz sont en légère avance à 0 9,16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land, moins bien tenue, mollit à 1 5/8-11/16. Les Estates sont en progrès à 0 5/8-11/16, tandis que leur part s'affaisse à 2 7/8. L'Abonkir est en bonne tendance à 27/9 et les Oasis à 0 1/2-9 16.
Le marché des valeurs étant fermé les samedis pendant la saison d'été, le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire ne paraîtra que le Lundi 16 Septembre courant.

Les milieux financiers américains ont enregistré avec beaucoup de satisfaction les récentes déclarations de M. Schaw, le prédécesseur de M. Cortelyou au département du Trésor, actuellement président d'un des plus grands établissements financiers de New York, la Carnegie Trust Co., qui parlant de la crise américaine, a déclaré :

"Ne perdons pas la tête.” Les produits annuels de notre agriculture dépassent 6,500 millions de dollars et nous pouvons tabler cette année sur des récoltes au moins moyennes. Le rendement de nos mines est de plus de 1,500,000,000 de dollars, celui de nos forêts de 1,000,000,000 de dollars, aucune de ces sources de richesse n'est tarie. Nos usines, en dehors de celles qui préparent les denrées alimentaires, produisent par an 1,200,000,000 de dollars de marchandises. Aucun haut fourneau n'est éteint. Les chemins de fer encaissent chaque année plus de deux milliards de dollars ; leur prospérité ne s'est pas encore démentie. Bon an mal an nos chemins et autres industries distribuent en salaires près de 3,500,000,000 de dollars. Depuis plusieurs années, nous sommes encore à entendre parler de réduction de prix de la main d'oeuvre.

"La situation des entreprises industrielles ne doit pas être mesurée par les cours de leurs actions. Nous cherchons, sans la trouver, la cause matérielle de la crise. Nous entrons dans le domaine du sentiment, ici tout change. Si les déposants retirent leurs fonds des établissements financiers pour les cacher, si les hanques suppriment les facilités à leurs clients, si enfin le public s'arrête de consommer ; il est évident que les effets matériels de notre hallucination ne manqneront pas de se produire... Les crises de ce pays ont toujours été plus ou moins dues à l'imagination de ses cytoyenge 2

Nous prions instamment les personnes qui ne recevraient pas régulièrement cette Circulaire de nous aviser sans retard, afin que nons puissions prendre des mesures immédiates pour assurer la ponctualité du service d'expédition.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les versements devront être effectués aux guichets de la Société, rue Kasr-el-Nil, au Caire.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L’Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance dà Public qu'il sera procérlé, le Lundi trente Septembre courant, à neuf heures du matin, aux Magasins Généraux de Boulac, Caire, à la vente aux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, de cinq vieilles machines pour imprimerie avec leurs accessoires qui se trouvent à l'atelier de l'Imprimerie de l'Administration en face de la gare du Caire où on peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à midi, le Vendredi et jours fériés exceptés.

Les conditions de vente relatives à ces machines peuvent être consultées au Bureau de Mr. le Chef da Service des Magasins Généraux à Boulac, Caire, et à celui de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary, Alexandrie, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m., le Dimanche et jours fériés exceptés.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au préalable, verser à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration une somme de L.E. 5 (cinq Livres Egyptiennes) à titre de dépôt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jus. qu'à concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de l'offre agréée et enlever à ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans un délai de sept jours à compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront être faites sur papier timbré de trente millèmes, si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchères publiques et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le reçu du versement du dépôt provisoire, seront adressés par la poste sous pli recommandé à :- .

Monsieur le Chef du Service des Magasins des Chemins de fer de l'Etat à Boulac (Caire). et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure por tant la suscription suivante : "Offre pour achat de vieilles machines pour imprimerie."
Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L''Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 11 Septembre 1907. 30900-2-2

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the lates statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier
div.p: DE "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Le Supplement Commercial et Pinancier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de façon a pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autriobien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der-nières statistiques jusqu'a la veil:e de sa publi-cation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour ape année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
